courseTitle: Determination of Acetic Acid Concentration in Vinegar Using Titration

pageData.text: The goal of this experiment is to accurately determine the concentration of acetic acid in commercial vinegar. In Activity 1, the percent of acetic acid in the included vinegar sample is determined. In Activity 2, a different sample of vinegar will be used and titrated. Activity 3 is a paper activity to calculate the of the acetic acid based on sample pH data that is provided.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: Titration of Vinegar with Sodium Hydroxide - 45 minutes
Activity 2: Titration of Unknown Vinegar Sample with Sodium Hydroxide - 30 minutes
Activity 3: Calculations of pKa from Sample Lab Data - 15 minutes

Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: Titration of Vinegar with Sodium Hydroxide - 45 minutes

pageData.text: You may know acetic acid by its common name, vinegar. It is used for a variety of purposes, from cooking and cleaning, to softening your laundry. But did you know vinegar can also be used as a natural herbicide? The vinegar you find at the store has enough acetic acid to combat certain types of weeds. For example, broadleaf weeds, such as dandelions, are more susceptible to vinegar than grassy weeds; and younger weeds (having 1-2 leaves) are more adversely affected than older, more established weeds<sup class=bodySupscript>1</sup>. Some studies show the effectiveness of the vinegar-based herbicides is closely related to the concentration of the acetic acid in your product: the higher the concentration, the more effective the weed-killing properties. Use caution with stronger concentrations of vinegar as it can irritate your skin and eyes if not used properly. Keep in mind that applying a vinegar-based herbicide will only attack a plant’s leaves and stems; the roots are not affected so it is likely some weed species may return<sup class=bodySupscript>1</sup>.

1Stein, D., & Rumsey, K. (n.d.). 5 tips for using vinegar herbicides. Northwest Center for Alternatives to Pesticides. Retrieved April 27, 2022, from https://www.pesticide.org/vinegar_herbicides#:~:text=Research%20on%20varying%20concentrations%20of%20acetic%20acid%20show,have%20turned%20up%20promising%20results%20for%20some%20weeds.?msclkid=f86088e7ac6811ec820b247f7e26cd1e

pageData.desc: A dandelion plant growing from a crack in a sidewalk.
pageData.altText: A dandelion plant growing from a crack in a sidewalk.

pageData.text: Aqueous solutions fall into one of three categories—, , or neutral—depending on the number of hydrogen ions and hydroxide ions present. Water molecules constantly dissociate into H+ and OH-, which then come back together to re-form water molecules. It should be noted that the H+ ion does not actually exist as such in an aqueous solution. Rather, H+ ions will associate with adjacent oxygen atoms, forming hydronium ions .
However, for the sake of convenience in our discussion of pH, we will refer to H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup> rather than H<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>O<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>.

The ranges from 0 to 14. The neutral center of the scale, 7, represents the amount of H+ per liter of water at 25 °C, which is equal to 1 × 10-7 moles. Solutions with a pH of less than 7 possess more H+ and fewer OH- ions, and are considered acidic. Solutions with a pH greater than 7 possess less than 1 × 10-7 H+ (and therefore more OH-) and are considered basic, or alkaline. A solution with an equal number of H+ and OH- is considered neutral. Note that, because pH values are based upon logarithms of the base 10, each pH value varies from the next by a factor of 10 in terms of strength. For example, a solution with a pH of 5 is 10 times more acidic than one with a pH of 6.

pageData.question: Which statement best describes an acidic solution?

options.text: a solution with more hydrogen ions than hydroxide ions
a solution with less than 1 × 10<sup class=bodySupscript>-7</sup> hydrogen ions
a solution with an equal number of hydrogen and hydroxide ions
a solution with more hydroxide ions than hydrogen ions
a solution with more hydroxide ions than hydronium ions

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Solutions with a pH of less than 7 (acidic) have more hydrogen ions, and therefore fewer hydroxide ions.

pageData.question: Solution A has a pH of 7 and Solution B has a pH of 9. Which of the following best describes the difference between these solutions?

options.text: Solution B is 100 times more basic than Solution A.
Solution B is twice as basic as Solution A.
Solution B is twice as acidic as Solution A.
Solution B is 10 times more basic than Solution A.
Solution B is 20 times more acidic than Solution A.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: pH values are based upon logarithms of the base 10, so each pH value varies from the next by a factor of 10 in terms of strength. Solution B is higher on the pH scale (meaning it has fewer hydrogen ions and more hydroxide ions) than Solution A by two pH values, which means it has 100 (10<sup class=bodySupscript>2</sup>) times the hydroxide ions of Solution A.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Solutions with a pH of less than 7 possess more H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup> (hydrogen ions) and fewer OH<sup class=bodySupscript>-</sup> (hydroxide ions), and are considered acidic. Solutions with a pH greater than 7 possess less than 1 × 10-7 H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup> (and therefore more OH<sup class=bodySupscript>-</sup>) and are considered basic, or alkaline. A solution with an equal number of H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup> and OH<sup class=bodySupscript>-</sup> is considered neutral. Note that, because pH values are based upon logarithms of the base 10, each pH value varies from the next by a factor of 10 in terms of strength.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Solutions with a pH of less than 7 possess more H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup> (hydrogen ions) and fewer OH<sup class=bodySupscript>-</sup> (hydroxide ions), and are considered acidic. Solutions with a pH greater than 7 possess less than 1 × 10-7 H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup> (and therefore more OH<sup class=bodySupscript>-</sup>) and are considered basic, or alkaline. A solution with an equal number of H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup> and OH<sup class=bodySupscript>-</sup> is considered neutral. Note that, because pH values are based upon logarithms of the base 10, each pH value varies from the next by a factor of 10 in terms of strength.

pageData.text: It is useful to be able to determine the pH of an aqueous solution if the amount of <button class='glossary-text'>H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup></button> is known; likewise, sometimes one knows the pH of the solution but needs to deduce the amount of H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>. Brackets in an equation, such as [H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>] below, refer to the concentration.
To determine pH when [H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>] is known, use the following formula:
pH = -log[H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>]
For example: Determine the pH of an aqueous solution in which [H+] = 1 × 10-3 M.
pH = -log[H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>] = -log(1 × 10<sup class=bodySupscript>-3</sup>) = 3
To determine [H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>] when the pH of a solution is known, use the same formula. The notation “inv log” refers to the inverse log.
For example: An aqueous solution has a pH of 5.5. Determine [H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>] in M (moles/liter).
pH = -log[H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>] = 5.5
log[H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>] = -5.5
[H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>] = inv log (-5.5) = 3.2 × 10<sup class=bodySupscript>-6</sup> M

Vinegar, a widely used preservative, cleaning product, and cooking ingredient, is a solution of acetic acid (CH<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>H). Different types of vinegar are produced through the fermentation of a wide variety of fruits and grains. Distilled white vinegar is produced by the fermentation of alcohol derived mainly from corn.

A <button class='glossary-text'>titration</button> is the precise addition of a solution of known concentration and composition, called the <button class='glossary-text'>titrant</button>, to a solution of unknown concentration or composition, called the <button class='glossary-text'>analyte</button>. In this acid-base titration, the titrant, sodium hydroxide, is delivered through a syringe in order to measure precisely (±0.1 mL) the volume of base added. In many traditional acid-base titrations, the titrant is added using a <button class='glossary-text'>burette</button>, a piece of glassware designed for adding known volumes of a solution to another container. Acetic acid, a weak acid, can be neutralized with a strong base, such as sodium hydroxide, to form a salt and water. The concentration of acetic acid, the analyte, in vinegar can be determined through an acid-base titration.
CH<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>H + NaOH → NaCH<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> + H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O

At the <button class='glossary-text'>equivalence point</button> of a titration, the moles of acid added is exactly equal to the moles of base in the solution before the titration started. The equivalence point is achieved when sufficient titrant has been added to react with all of the analyte. The <button class='glossary-text'>end point</button> is the experimental estimate of the equivalence point, and is typically identified by a color change in an indicator solution. In a titration, there is a noticeable change in pH near the end point. A change in color of an indicator added to the analyte at the start of the titration is observed when the end point has been reached. The molarity and volume of the titrant are known, as is the volume of the analyte. To determine the concentration of the analyte, first determine the number of moles of titrant that were needed to reach the end point. Next, use the balanced chemical equation to calculate the moles of analyte present. Finally, use the volume of the analyte to find the concentration of the analyte.

The pH range of the indicator used for a given must include the pH change of the . Acid-base indicators are weak organic acids that change color depending on the pH of the solution. The pH range of an indicator is the range of pH values over which the color change occurs when the indicator converts between its and forms. This range depends on the strength of the indicator’s acid form and, therefore, varies among indicators. Phenolphthalein is the indicator used in this experiment. Phenolphthalein is colorless in its acidic form and pink in its basic form. The of this indicator is 9, and it has a pH range of 8-10, which is appropriate for the titration to be performed.

It is important to remember that acids and bases will dissociate in aqueous solutions. The is the equilibrium constant of the dissociation reaction of an acid in aqueous solution, representing a dynamic balance between the acid in its intact and dissociated states. The pKa is a simplified representation of Ka.
The pKa of the acetic acid can easily be calculated using the data obtained in this lab and the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation:
pH = pKa + log[A-]/[HA]
pKa = -log Ka
The Ka, the acid dissociation constant, is the equilibrium constant for the dissociation reaction:
HA ↔︎ <button class='glossary-text'>H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup></button> + A<sup class=bodySupscript>-</sup>

where an acid (HA) dissociates to form its conjugate base (A-) and a hydrogen ion (H+). Because the value of Ka can vary over several orders of magnitude, it is convenient to use the -log of this number, the pKa, for reference. In the pKa equation, [A-] is the molar concentration of the anion and [HA] is the molar concentration of the acid. For practical purposes, the pKa should be equal to the pH at the of a titration. The midpoint is the volume that is halfway to the end point of a titration. At the midpoint, [HA] = [A-] and the pH measured at the midpoint can be used to experimentally determine the pKa.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the equivalence point of a titration?

options.text: The moles of acid and base in the titration solution are equal.
The mass of titrant used is equal to the mass of analyte before the titration started.
The pH of the analyte equals the pH of the titrant.
The pK<sub class=bodySubscript>a</sub> of the titration solution is zero.
The pH of the titrant is 7.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The equivalence point is achieved when sufficient titrant has been added to react with all the analyte. In an acid-base titration, this means the moles of acid and base in the solution are equal and the solution is neutralized.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the end point of an acid-base titration?

options.text: when the titration solution changes color
when the titration solution doubles in volume
when the volume of titrant added equals the initial volume of analyte
when a salt precipitates out of the titration solution
when the pH of the titrant and the pH of the analyte are equal

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The end point is the experimental estimate of the equivalence point, and is typically identified by a color change in an indicator solution.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: A titration is the precise addition of a solution of known concentration and composition, called the titrant, to a solution of unknown concentration or composition, called the analyte. In the acid-base titration to be performed in this investigation, the titrant, sodium hydroxide, is delivered through a syringe in order to measure precisely (±0.1 mL) the volume of base added to a sample of vinegar, the analyte, to determine its concentration of acetic acid. Acetic acid is a weak acid and can be neutralized with a strong base, such as sodium hydroxide, to form a salt and water. At the equivalence point of such a titration, the moles of acid are exactly equal to the moles of base in the solution before the titration started. The equivalence point is achieved when sufficient titrant has been added to react with all the analyte. Experimentally, this point is typically identified by a color change in a pH indicator solution and is referred to as the end point of the titration.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: A titration is the precise addition of a solution of known concentration and composition, called the titrant, to a solution of unknown concentration or composition, called the analyte. In the acid-base titration to be performed in this investigation, the titrant, sodium hydroxide, is delivered through a syringe in order to measure precisely (±0.1 mL) the volume of base added to a sample of vinegar, the analyte, to determine its concentration of acetic acid. Acetic acid is a weak acid and can be neutralized with a strong base, such as sodium hydroxide, to form a salt and water. At the equivalence point of such a titration, the moles of acid are exactly equal to the moles of base in the solution before the titration started. The equivalence point is achieved when sufficient titrant has been added to react with all the analyte. Experimentally, this point is typically identified by a color change in a pH indicator solution and is referred to as the end point of the titration.

pageData.desc: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, you will measure the mass of vinegar and the amount of sodium hydroxide used to titrate the vinegar. You will then calculate the average acetic acid concentration. In Activity 2, you will repeat the procedure from Activity 1 to determine the acetic acid concentration of a vinegar sample you have collected.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Activity sections.
Phenolphthalein is an alcohol based solution. Keep chemical away from any heat or flame sources.
Acetic acid and sodium hydroxide are corrosive. In the event of contact with skin or eyes, the affected area should be immediately rinsed with water for 15 minutes.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

pageData.text: In Activity 1, you will perform three trials of a <button class='glossary-text'>titration</button> of vinegar (<button class='glossary-text'>analyte</button>) using sodium hydroxide (<button class='glossary-text'>titrant</button>), with phenolphthalein as the indicator. By measuring the mass of vinegar and the amount of sodium hydroxide used to titrate the vinegar, you will be able to calculate the percent mass of acetic acid in the vinegar sample.

pages.title: Titration of Vinegar with Sodium Hydroxide (18 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Titration of Vinegar with Sodium Hydroxide (18 steps)

pageData.text: Place the 10-mL graduated cylinder on the electronic balance.
Tare the balance.
Dispense ~ 5 mL of vinegar into the graduated cylinder with a plastic pipet.
Record the exact mass of vinegar in Data Table 1.
Transfer the vinegar into the clean 25-mL Erlenmeyer flask.
Add 2 drops of phenolphthalein to the vinegar. Take photograph of flask as the start point of the <button class='glossary-text'>titration</button>.
Transfer approximately 10 mL of 1 M sodium hydroxide (NaOH) to the small cup. This solution will be used to fill the syringe.
Fill the syringe with 1 M NaOH solution.Try to minimize the amount of air in the syringe.
Record the initial volume of NaOH solution in the syringe to the nearest 0.1 mL in Data Table 1 for Vinegar Sample 1. Read the volume of the syringe at the edge of the plunger.
Place the flask containing the 5.0 mL of vinegar on the white sheet of paper. The white background will make the color change more noticeable.
Add NaOH from the syringe in 0.5-mL increments, swirling the flask between each addition until a color change persists for a few seconds after the addition of the NaOH.

Add NaOH dropwise from the syringe, with constant swirling, until a single drop of NaOH causes a color change that persists for a few seconds after the addition. This indicates that the has been reached.
To gain more control of single drops from the syringe, move the plunger by holding it where it enters the syringe instead of pressing the end of the plunger.
Once the end point has been reached, record the final volume of NaOH in the syringe in Data Table 1 for Vinegar Sample 1. Take photograph of flask as the end point of the titration.
Calculate the total volume of NaOH that was required to reach the end point and record the data in Data Table 1.
Dispose of the titrated vinegar sample in the sink.
Rinse the 25-mL flask three times with water.
Repeat steps 1-16 for Vinegar columns 2 and 3 on the Data Table 1.

Calculate the concentration of acetic acid in your vinegar sample based on your experimental data The molar mass of acetic acid is 60.05 g/mol. See the following example:Example:
A sample of 10.0 grams of HCI solution of unknown concentration is titrated to the end point with 6.2 mL of a 1.0 M NaOH sample. Calculate the concentration of hydrochloric acid.
  1. Calculate the volume of HCl solution.
    Volume = Mass / Density
    Volume = 10.00 g / 1.00 g/mL = 10.00 mL
  2. Determine the moles of sodium hydroxide used to reach the end point.
    Moles of NaOH = 1.0 M × 6.2 mL × 1 L / 1,000 mL = 0.0062 moles NaOH
  3. Determine the moles of hydrochloric acid in the sample.
    Moles of NaOH = Moles of HCl at the
    Moles of NaOH = 0.0062 moles = Moles of HCl
  4. Calculate the molarity of hydrochloric acid.
    0.0062 moles / 0.010 L = 0.62 M HCl
  5. Calculate the mass of hydrochloric acid in the initial sample.
    Mass of HCl = Moles of HCl / Molar Mass of HCl
    Mass of HCl = 0.0062 mol × 36.46 g/mol = 0.23 g
  6. Calculate the percent mass of hydrochloric acid in the initial sample.
    Percent Mass = (Mass of Solute / Total mass) × 100
    Percent Mass = (Mass of HCl / Mass of solution) × 100
    Percent Mass = (0.23 g / 10.00 g) x 100 = 2.3 %
In Activity 2, you will repeat the procedure from Activity 1 to determine the acetic acid concentration of a vinegar sample you have collected.

pages.title: Titration of an Unknown Vinegar Sample with Sodium Hydroxide
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Titration of an Unknown Vinegar Sample with Sodium Hydroxide

pageData.text: Activity 2 is an inquiry-based activity to demonstrate the learned technique of determining the acetic acid concentration in vinegar to a vinegar sample from your home. Each type of vinegar has a slightly different concentration of acetic acid. This activity requires the selection of a vinegar product from your home, a friend’s home, or a local restaurant. Only about a teaspoon of vinegar is needed. Attempt to find a different type of vinegar such as cider, malt, or balsamic vinegar. The vinegar included in this kit is white vinegar. Different brands of vinegar may also contain different amounts of acetic acid. Use the same procedure and Data Table 2 to determine the acetic acid content in your vinegar sample.

pages.title: Calculations of pKa from Sample Lab Data
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Calculations of pKa from Sample Lab Data (5 steps)

typeBefore.text: The following activity is intended as an extension activity and requires the application of concepts from the Background and Activities 1 and 2 to solve a mathematical problem. The of acetic acid is 4.75, and the volume of vinegar is 21.05 mL.

pageData.text: Review the lab data found in Data Table 3. This is from a <button class='glossary-text'>titration</button> of a vinegar sample using a pH meter.
Determine the volume of 0.1 M NaOH dispensed during the titration. Record the answer.
Calculate the molarity of the acetic acid in the vinegar samples. Record the answers.
Calculate the pKa of acetic acid from the <button class='glossary-text'>midpoint</button> data using the Henderson-Hasselbach equations in the Background section.
Find the average calculated molarity, percent by mass concentration, and pKa for acetic acid based on the provided data.

text:
Given the following experimental data, calculate the molarity and the pKa of the acid (HA) in the titration, if the balance neutralization reaction is:
HA + NaOH → NaA + H2O.A pH reading of 3.65 was obtained when 13.0 mL of 0.413 M NaOH was added to the 25.0 mL analyte.The endpoint was achieved when 31.25 mL of NaOH had been added.

pageData.altText:
This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. 
In Activity 1, you will measure the mass of vinegar and the amount of sodium hydroxide used to titrate the vinegar. You will then calculate the average acetic acid concentration. 
In Activity 2, you will repeat the procedure from Activity 1 to determine the acetic acid concentration of a vinegar sample you have collected.

pageData.content: Setting up and Performing a Titration

data.title: Acid dissociation constant (K<sub class=bodySubscript>a</sub>)
data.content: The equilibrium constant of the dissociation reaction of an acid in aqueous solution, representing a dynamic balance between the acid in its intact and dissociated states.

data.title: Acidic
data.content: Describes solutions with a pH of less than 7.

data.title: Analyte
data.content: A solution of unknown concentration or composition.

data.title: Basic
data.content: Describes solutions with a pH of greater than 7; also called alkaline.

data.title: Burette
data.content: A piece of glassware designed for adding known volumes of a solution to another container.

data.title: End point
data.content: The end point is the experimental estimate of the equivalence point and is typically identified by a color change in an indicator solution.

data.title: Equivalence point
data.content: At the equivalence point of a titration, the moles of acid added is exactly equal to the moles of base in the solution before the titration started.

data.title: Midpoint
data.content: The midpoint is the volume that is halfway to the end point of a titration.

data.title: pH scale
data.content: The logarithmic scale from 0 to 14 that describes the hydrogen ion concentration of solutions.

data.title: pK<sub class=bodySubscript>a</sub>
data.content: A simplified representation of K<sub class=bodySubscript>a</sub>.

data.title: Titrant
data.content: A solution of known concentration and composition.

data.title: Titration
data.content: the precise addition of a solution of known concentration and composition to a solution of unknown concentration or composition.
